Get started

Source: vignettes/r2dii.Rmd
r2dii.Rmd

As usual, start by using the r2dii package with:

library(r2dii)
#> Loading required package: r2dii.dataraw
#> Loading required package: r2dii.utils

Creating data snapshots

take_snapshot() allows you to take snapshots of multiple datasets. Its default behavior is sensible, but conservative and potentially slow (see take_snapshot()). You may want to change the default arguments.

Use:

  • datasets to snapshot specific datasets.
  • Use destdir to customize the destination directory.
  • Use config to provide a custom configuration file to take_snapshot().
datasets <- c("RevenueSplit", "BENCH.REGIONS")
custom_destdir <- tempdir()
custom_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")

take_snapshot(
  datasets,
  destdir = custom_destdir, 
  config = custom_config
)
#> Wrote 'config-toy.yml' to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/config-toy.yml'.
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'readr':
#>   method           from 
#>   format.col_spec  vroom
#>   print.col_spec   vroom
#>   print.collector  vroom
#>   print.date_names vroom
#>   print.locale     vroom
#>   str.col_spec     vroom
#> Wrote `BENCH.REGIONS` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/BENCH.REGIONS.csv'.

Use:

  • overwrite = TRUE to overwrite existing snapshots.
take_snapshot(
  datasets,
  destdir = custom_destdir, 
  config = custom_config
)
#> Skipping existing snapshot of 'config-toy.yml'.
#> Skipping existing snapshot of `RevenueSplit`.
#> Skipping existing snapshot of `BENCH.REGIONS`.

# Overwrite
take_snapshot(
  datasets,
  destdir = custom_destdir, 
  config = custom_config,
  overwrite = TRUE
)
#> Wrote 'config-toy.yml' to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/config-toy.yml'.
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Wrote `BENCH.REGIONS` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/BENCH.REGIONS.csv'.
  • options(r2dii_config = <custom_config>) replaces config and affects your R session globally.
restore <- options(r2dii_config = custom_config)

take_snapshot(
  datasets,
  destdir = custom_destdir, 
  overwrite = TRUE
)
#> Wrote 'config-toy.yml' to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/config-toy.yml'.
#> Wrote `RevenueSplit` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/RevenueSplit.csv'.
#> Wrote `BENCH.REGIONS` to 'C:/Users/Mauro/AppData/Local/Temp/RtmpmY5wuR/BENCH.REGIONS.csv'.

options(restore)

Documentation

You can access the high level documentation of the package with ?r2dii.dataraw. At the bottom you may click Index to access the help files of all topics. As usual, you can access the help file of any topic with ?topic.

A good way to learn about discover useful features is to run a Global search using a keyword, or to navigate the table of Contents. In any case, click on the question mark next to the name of any feature to access its documentation.

Create paths

A family of functions create robust paths.

path_dropbox_2dii()
#> C:/Users/Mauro/Dropbox (2° Investing)

(For you, the root directory might be similar to C:/Users/You/...)

Configuration file

A family of functions help you to deal with the configuration file.

edit_config() opens the default configuration file so you can edit it.

if (interactive()) edit_config()

(I’m not in an interactive session so the chunk above won’t run.)

get_config() outputs a path to a configuration file. By default it outputs the path to a toy configuration file with a warning.

default_config <- get_config()
#> Warning: Using a toy configuration file.
#> You may use your configuration file with `options(r2dii_config = 'path/to/config.yml')`

show_config() shows a configuration file.

show_config(default_config, n_max = 5)
default:
  Methodology:
    HasBookValue: FALSE # ignore
    HasRISK: TRUE # ignore a flag specifying if the physical risk assessment should be done
    HasMAP: TRUE # flag to specify if map data (production per country) should be prepared

Most analyses should start by setting a custom configuration file globally with options().

your_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")
restore <- options(r2dii_config = your_config)

get_config()
[1] "C:/Users/Mauro/Documents/R/win-library/3.6/r2dii.utils/config-toy.yml"

show_config(get_config())
default:
  Expect:
   param_a: a
   param_1: 1
   param_true: TRUE
   param_false: FALSE
   param_unset:
  TimeStamps:
    ALD.Timestamp: 3333
    FinancialData.Timestamp: 2018Q3

options(restore)

Access configuration parameters and create configuration-sensitive paths

A family of functions are sensitive to the configuration file you use. This includes all functions to access configuration parameters, and some of the functions to create paths.

a_config <- example_config("config_2019Q2.yml")
restore <- options(r2dii_config = a_config)

FINANCIAL.TIMESTAMP()
#> [1] "2019Q2"

another_config <- example_config("config-toy.yml")
options(r2dii_config = another_config)

FINANCIAL.TIMESTAMP()
#> [1] "2018Q3"

options(restore)

Extending functions to access configuration parameters

Eventually you will likely need to access new configuration parameters. How would you expand this family of functions?

To show you how let me first create a mini configuration file and save it to a temporary directory.

# Create an example configuration file
config <- glue::glue("
   default:
     a_field: a_value
 ")

show_config(config)
  default:
    a_field: a_value

# Write the config file to a temporary file
config_file <- tempfile()
readr::write_lines(config, config_file)

Use get_param() to create new functions to access configuration parameters. Here, for example, get_a_value() gets a_value from a_field:

get_a_value <- get_param("a_field")
get_a_value(file = config_file)
#> [1] "a_value"

Datasets

A family of functions allow you to read local datasets from your local 2dii Dropbox-folder, e.g.:

INDEX.REGIONS()
#> # A tibble: 327 x 3
#>    EquityMarket Country             CountryISO
#>    <chr>        <chr>               <chr>     
#>  1 Global       Afghanistan         AF        
#>  2 Global       Albania             AL        
#>  3 Global       Algeria             DZ        
#>  4 Global       American Samoa      AS        
#>  5 Global       Andorra             AD        
#>  6 Global       Angola              AO        
#>  7 Global       Anguilla            AI        
#>  8 Global       Antigua And Barbuda AG        
#>  9 Global       Argentina           AR        
#> 10 Global       Armenia             AM        
#> # ... with 317 more rows

GROUPS.GOVT()
#>  [1] "Sovereign"              "Sovereign Agency"      
#>  [3] "Municipal"              "Municipal-City"        
#>  [5] "Municipal-County"       "Multi-National"        
#>  [7] "Regional"               "Regional(state/provnc)"
#>  [9] "Export/Import Bank"     "Regional Authority"    
#> [11] "Regional Agencies"

Remember that the datasets you get may be sensitive to the configuration file. If in doubt, check which file are you using with get_config().
